title: The Locust Plague and Call to Repentance
shortSummary: Joel chapter 1 describes a devastating locust plague that has ravaged the land, destroying crops and causing widespread mourning among the people and priests. The prophet calls the community to lament, fast, and seek the Lord’s mercy in light of this calamity, which foreshadows the coming Day of the Lord.
timeline: c. 9th to 7th century BC - Period of the early prophets in Judah

keyCharacters.name: Joel
keyCharacters.description: The prophet and son of Pethuel who delivers God's message of warning and calls for repentance.

keyCharacters.name: The priests
keyCharacters.description: Ministers of the Lord’s altar who mourn the interruption of offerings and lead the people in lamentation.

keyCharacters.name: The inhabitants of the land
keyCharacters.description: The people of Judah who are called to hear the warning, lament the destruction, and respond in repentance.

definitions.definition: A type of locust or caterpillar that devastates crops, used here to describe the first wave of the locust plague.
A grain or cereal offering presented to God as an act of worship, symbolizing dedication and fellowship with Him.
A coarse, rough fabric worn as a sign of mourning, repentance, and humility before God.
A future time of divine judgment and restoration when God will intervene decisively in history.

outline.heading: Introduction and Call to Hear (Joel 1:1-3)
outline.description: Joel introduces himself as the prophet and urgently calls the elders and all inhabitants to listen and remember if such devastation has happened before, emphasizing the importance of passing this warning to future generations.

outline.heading: Description of the Locust Plague (Joel 1:4-7)
outline.description: A vivid depiction of the locust invasion that has consumed everything, from crops to trees, illustrating the severity of the disaster as a judgment from God.

outline.heading: Call to Lamentation and Mourning (Joel 1:8-13)
outline.description: Joel exhorts all—drunkards, farmers, priests—to mourn deeply, using imagery of loss and desolation to highlight the spiritual and physical impact of the plague.

outline.heading: Call to Fasting and Assembly (Joel 1:14-15)
outline.description: The prophet commands a sacred fast and solemn assembly, recognizing the coming Day of the Lord as a time of impending judgment and urging the people to seek God earnestly.

outline.heading: The Devastation’s Impact on Land and Creatures (Joel 1:16-20)
outline.description: The chapter closes with a lament over the ruined crops, barren fields, and suffering animals, emphasizing the comprehensive nature of the disaster and the urgent need for divine intervention.

application: Recognize and respond to God’s warnings with humility and repentance before judgment comes.
Engage in corporate and personal fasting and prayer to seek God’s mercy in times of crisis.
Teach future generations about God’s faithfulness and the consequences of sin through faithful storytelling and instruction.
Mourn sincerely over spiritual and physical losses as a step toward restoration and renewal.

keyVerses.text: Sanctify ye a fast, call a solemn assembly, gather the elders and all the inhabitants of the land into the house of the LORD your God, and cry unto the LORD,
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the proper response to calamity—humble fasting, corporate repentance, and seeking God’s help.

keyVerses.text: Alas for the day! for the day of the LORD is at hand, and as a destruction from the Almighty shall it come.
keyVerses.significance: It warns of the coming Day of the Lord, a key theme in Joel, emphasizing the certainty and severity of God’s judgment.

keyVerses.text: That which the palmerworm hath left hath the locust eaten; and that which the locust hath left hath the cankerworm eaten; and that which the cankerworm hath left hath the caterpiller eaten.
keyVerses.significance: This verse vividly portrays the thoroughness of the devastation, symbolizing the completeness of God’s judgment.
